info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued February 19 at 12:54PM EST until February 19 at 1:15PM EST by NWS State College
info.description: ...A SNOW SQUALL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 115 PM EST FOR CENTRAL SCHUYLKILL...NORTHERN DAUPHIN...FRANKLIN...SOUTHEASTERN FULTON...CENTRAL CUMBERLAND AND SOUTHEASTERN PERRY COUNTIES... At 1254 PM EST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from Arrowhead Lake to New Philadelphia to Rockville to Scotland to Big Cove Tannery, moving east at 50 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts greater than 30 mph. SOURCE...Radar and webcams. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. This includes the following Interstates... Interstate 70 from mile markers 167 to 170. The Pennsylvania Turnpike from mile markers 213 to 230. Interstate 81 between mile markers 1 and 59...between mile markers 61 and 64...and from mile markers 106 to 139. Locations impacted include... Chambersburg, Carlisle, Pottsville, Waynesboro, Shippensburg, Shenandoah, Greencastle, St. Clair, McConnellsburg, Guilford, Plainfield, St. Thomas, Schlusser, Minersville, Mahanoy City, Frackville, Fayetteville, Warfordsburg, Ashland and Marysville. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. There is no safe place on a highway when a snow squall hits. Visibility and traction are immediately lost in whiteout conditions, making it difficult or impossible to slow down and avoid stopped vehicles. Delay travel or safely exit the highway before the snow squall arrives. Wet roadways will quickly freeze. Black ice will cause roads, bridges and overpasses to become slick and dangerous. Slow down and be prepared for sudden loss of traction.
